content:

[[module Rate]]
[[/>]]

[[=]]

+ 6kollages:

The quality of work submitted for the 6000 Contest has been staggering - but not surprising. These collages[[footnote]] To be clear, I mashed existing images together. Feel free to peruse the "Image Sources" for, well the sources of the images! They're all CC-compliant! [[/footnote]] are inspired by some of those works whose use of imagery caught my attention. I hope you enjoy them; whether or not you do, the articles are all worth a read!

I'm planning on doing some more while voting continues, and releasing them in batches, so if you have a suggestion feel free to mention it in the comments![[footnote]] Suggesting your own is not only allowed, it is **encouraged!** [[/footnote]][[footnote]] If you are suggesting something, feel free to mention what imagery it calls to mind for you! [[/footnote]]

-----

{{I had to downsize the images. Please let me know[[footnote]] Shoot me a Wikidot PM or leave a comment! Or ping me on IRC! [[/footnote]] if you want any in their full, crisp, glossy, high-resolution glory!}}

++ [*http://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/scp-6002 All Creatures Great and Small]

//"I want command to see this. The master’s tools will never dismantle the master’s house."//

Author: [[*user bigslothonmyface]]

> There is, unfortunately, no image for this one. I really //wanted// there to be. Sloth's work is fantastic, and you should all read it if you haven't yet. 
> 
> When I started trying to put together a collage for this entry, I knew I wanted the central image to be from an artist from the Indigenous Peoples identified in the work: the "Klamath tribes of northern California." I've spent a lot of time looking for artwork to use, but haven't (yet) been able to find anything that fits the imagery of Sloth's piece and is CC-compliant. To be //__very__// clear, this is not because that art doesn't exist - Indigenous Peoples today are making absolutely incredible artworks that engage with their personal, cultural, and historical identities as well as the ongoing effects of colonialism. Most of the artworks used in these collages are public domain, meaning the artist died 70 years or more ago.[[footnote]] Or 95 years past the date of publication if produced by a corporation. [[/footnote]] Because of western conceptions of what is 'art,' finding historic, public domain works by Dürer and Monet is easy. Finding works from that time period by Indigenous artists is much less so; not because such works don't (and/or didn't) exist, but because of attempts to destroy the cultural identities of these peoples. 
> 
> I tried to work around this and made some early mock-ups involving a few different depictions of trees, including [*https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Darwin_Tree_1837.png Darwin's "I Think" sketch]: his early depiction of the branching tree of life. However, these felt wrong. Centering a western representation of this subject matter ignored, rather than paid homage to, the message of Sloth's work. 
> 
> I am a white settler living on Miꞌkmaꞌki, the unceded and unsurrendered territory of the Miꞌkmaq People. If I am unable to properly represent the culture that is so integral to this marvelous work, I shouldn't attempt to at all. 
> 
> Instead, I would like to provide links to a few contemporary Indigenous artists & associated art exhibitions:
> 
> * [*https://www.kentmonkman.com/ Kent Monkman]: [*https://moa.ubc.ca/exhibition/shame-and-prejudice/ "SHAME AND PREJUDICE"]
> * [*https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Pitsiulak Tim Pitsiulak] and [*https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenojuak_Ashevak Kenojuak Ashevak]: [*https://ago.ca/exhibitions/tunirrusiangit-kenojuak-ashevak-and-tim-pitsiulak "TUNIRRUSIANGIT"]
> * [*https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rick_Bartow Rick Bartow] (along side 40+ other artists): [*https://www.crockerart.org/exhibitions/when-i-remember-i-see-red "WHEN I REMEMBER I SEE RED"]
> 
> I haven't given up on making one for //All Creatures Great and Small,// however. So hopefully one day I'll have something to add here. 
> 
> If there are Indigenous artists, contemporary or historic, whose work(s) you find compelling, please feel free to share links in the comments.

++ [*http://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/scp-6003 Beacon]

//"And he said unto Lothos, 'Traverse the Seas, the Waters of the World, though come not to that place!'"//

Authors: [[*user PlaguePJP]], [[*user J Dune]], & [[*user AnActualCrow]].

[[=image Beacon-f.jpg]]

{{This was my first attempt at //Beacon//. But I wasn't quite happy with it. The article has such an incredibly oppressive atmosphere of dread that just permeates the entire piece. While I tried to mirror the imagery, my end result seemed too clean and tidy to really capture what I was going for. So I started fresh and had a second go at it. Personally, I'm happier with the second one: it's darker, more abstracted, and hopefully unnerving in a way the former image isn't.}}

[[=image Beacon2-f.jpg]]
